newsitem.title: UK: UK's BBC defends executive pay rises.
newsitem.headline: UK's BBC defends executive pay rises.

text.p: The chairman of the BBC on Monday defended a pay rise of almost 20 percent awarded to the corporation's director-general last year.

Director-general John Birt, whose cost-saving and restructuring measures have provoked great controversy, received 354,000 pounds ($598,000) in salary, bonus and benefits in 1996/97 -- up from 299,000 pounds last year.
The increase provoked criticism from sections of the media and angered unions who accused the BBC, mainly funded by an annual licence fee levy on the public, of paying "private sector wages".
BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland, part of the committee which awarded the rise, said the BBC had to pay figures which were broadly in line with the market.

"We used extensive outside surveys. These figures were not lightly arrived at. We think it was appropriate to fix these salary levels," he said. Bland said that almost all of the BBC's leading executives could command higher salaries if they were to seek jobs outside the corporation.

He noted that Birt's salary was roughly comparable to that of Richard Eyre, chief executive of commerical broadcaster Capital Radio Plc or Nigel Walmsley, a director of commercial TV company Carlton Communications Plc.

Members of the BBC's 10-strong executive committee also enjoy perks such as chauffeur-driven cars for business use and a company car and free petrol for private use. Bland said these fringe benefits were in line with the average in industry.($ = 0.591 British Pounds)
